title: Why I’m running the Boston Marathon for charity after 9/11 — and what it means to me
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Matt Marino, 48, from Bernardsville, NJ, is running the 2026 Boston Marathon for the Webb Norden Foundation.
The Webb Norden Foundation was founded by Boston Marathon bombing survivors to aid children recovering from trauma.
Marino's motivation stems from personal 9/11 trauma, hoping to provide resources to others in need through fundraising.

title: Treated at Mass. Eye and Ear as a teen, she’s now running the Boston Marathon to give back
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Mary Ellen Burt, 37 from Chelmsford, is running the 2026 Boston Marathon to support Mass Eye and Ear.
Burt, treated at Mass Eye and Ear as a teen for sinus and septum issues, is raising funds through her run.
The Boston Marathon participant appreciates Mass Eye and Ear's dedication to improving patients' quality of life.

title: New Mass. and Cass recommendations could mark major shift in strategy
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Boston officials propose expanding police and case manager units to address addiction and homelessness at Mass. and Cass.
Working group recommends creating a 'specialty court' for drug offenders, focusing on treatment over criminal charges.
Proposal potentially shifts focus from harm reduction strategies, like needle distribution, to stricter measures against public drug use.

title: Massachusetts is 1 of 4 states that lost private-sector jobs over the last five years
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Massachusetts lost roughly 24,000 private-sector jobs from January 2020 to March 2025, a 0.74% decrease.
The state's GDP has lagged behind the national average since 2022, impacting its competitive economic advantages.
Migration out of Massachusetts is influenced by job losses, high living costs, and better opportunities in other states.

title: What is happening with the Central Square sign?
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Central Square's iconic rainbow sign removed for refurbishment due to graffiti and damage; original artists managing the update.
Sign originally a Blockbuster video sign, revamped in 2018 with a new rainbow design for the diverse community.
Reinstallation party planned for March 13 with a brewery collaboration and new lighting to celebrate sign's return.

title: Lifelong skiers say this New England ski resort is among the best in the U.S., according to Travel + Leisure
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Killington Ski Resort in Vermont is named among the top 15 ski resorts in the U.S. by Travel + Leisure.
Killington offers 155 trails, 22 lifts, and 1,509 skiable acres, debuting a new high-speed, six-person chairlift this season.
The resort is praised for its 'old-school' East Coast feel and international amenities, and often remains open until June.

title: Dine Out Boston: What’s new, best deals, and best meals for winter 2026
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Dine Out Boston runs from February 22 to March 7 with 140 participating restaurants.
Prices for Dine Out Boston range from $27 for lunch to $55 for dinner, with varying course options.
New participants include Nowon and The Block at Woods Hill offering diverse cuisines from Korean-American to farm-to-table.

title: ‘I would like to apologize to Jaylen Brown’: Beverly Hills admits mistake in ending Celtics star’s event
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Beverly Hills apologized to Celtics' Jaylen Brown for shutting down his event during NBA All-Star weekend.
The city incorrectly claimed Brown's event lacked a permit, later admitting no application was submitted or denied.
Brown, considering legal action, criticized the apology for perpetuating inaccuracies and damaging his brand.

title: Emergency room wait times: Readers recount 10- to 30-hour ER stays
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Massachusetts ER visits have increased wait times, with some lasting up to 30 hours due to capacity issues.
Readers report varied ER experiences, from no wait at Cape Cod Falmouth ER to long delays at UMass Memorial.
Staffing shortages and limited inpatient beds contribute to extended ER waits, affecting patient care quality.

title: 14-year-old arrested after man kicked into moving train at Back Bay
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: A 14-year-old boy was arrested for allegedly kicking a man into a moving train at Back Bay Station.
The 27-year-old victim sustained a forehead injury but was conscious and alert when treated by medics.
The suspect faces charges of assault and battery with a dangerous weapon; police continue to investigate.
